This song hits me hard. I started experimenting with drugs when I was only 11 years old. I've lost family members & friends to drugs. I watched them slowly kill themselves & yet I couldn't pull myself away from drugs. I went down the same path to the point that I overdosed on multiple occasions & 2 of them were on purpose. I'd drink till I passed out & later wake up in the middle of nowhere & not remembering how I got there. Unfortunately when I 23 I overdosed trying to take my life cause I felt like there was no hope for me. Luckily someone went to my apartment & found me. I woke up a week later not remembering who I was. It took me around 2 days to start remembering things & people. I decided right then & there that I needed to save myself so I quit drugs & alcohol on the spot. The first 3 years of that journey were the hardest but here I am now at 36 years old & I'm clean. I'm still not emotionally or mentally in a good place but I can't allow myself to go back to that lifestyle cause I know for a fact that if I do I'll never make it back.

(SORRY FOR THE PARAGRAPH IN ADVANCEâ€¦) #triggerwarning #myfentanylstory  This video hurt my heart. Being on both sides of this, being the one who was addicted and being the one who deals with her motherâ€™s addiction, itâ€™s hard. I got addicted to opiates at 18 and got clean by 21. Stayed sober until I was 23 turning 24 when I started hanging out with my mom more often with her and her boyfriend. Heâ€™d go and buy these â€œperk 30sâ€ from a trailer that was parked in the neighborhood. At that time I knew nothing about fentanyl or just how serious it was. He told me one day when I was in the car with him as he was going to get some â€œthey sell perk 30s here for a cheap price.â€ I still donâ€™t know why heâ€™d tell a recovering addict that, but hey ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸ some things just donâ€™t make sense. So I bought one, loved how it made me feel. So I bought another the next day, and then another the next day, and another the next. Then next thing you know it was 6 months later and I was literally driving around doing DoorDash for 8-12 hours a day to cover my 5-8 pill a day habit, spending $3,000 a month. I struggled so damn hard every single day man. The days that I wasnâ€™t able to score were really super hard for me. If my dealer was out, Iâ€™d wait outside his house for hours and blow his phone up until he got more. If my car had issues and I wasnâ€™t able to make my money for that day, Iâ€™d sit in my bathtub and cry going back and forth from my bed to the tub with the worst cold sweats Iâ€™ve ever dealt with in my life. (And I thought perk withdrawal was bad, I didnâ€™t know SHIT until I felt fentanyl withdrawal.) oh and let me not even get started on the precipitated withdrawal I would get because I didnâ€™t understand that I had to wait atleast 7/8 days before I could take a suboxone, so Iâ€™d take one only 1 day into my withdrawal symptoms from fentanyl and Iâ€™d go into the worst withdrawal a person could ever deal with in their life. Iâ€™d sit in the tub and cry and watch YouTube videos about the statistics of addicts that are on fentanyl and how almost 90% of them either die or never get clean, so that was one of the most discouraging things Iâ€™ve ever read about. My poor 21 year old little brother was living with me at the time and would have to watch me in pain like that (even though I tried my best to hide it from him.) so I told him to drop me off to rehab because at that point I was done! I didnâ€™t want to keep working all day every day just to keep from being sick because at that point I wasnâ€™t even getting high anymore. I lasted in rehab for all of about a day and a half and had my brother come and pick me back up. Everyone was fed up with me and my shit. My older sister was the only one I had left and she took me in to her home and was hell bent on helping me get clean. The doctor told us he could help taper me off by taking little doses of suboxone and fentanyl together which would keep me from getting precipitated withdrawal. But me being able to still take the fentanyl wasnâ€™t working for me. Because at that point (like an addict does) I just wanted to feel the high, so all the progress I made during them couple of weeks at my sisters house was basically for nothing because I ended up leaving and going back to getting high. About a month after that, I tried something called â€œcolonopinâ€ (which honestly is a whole other drug that I couldâ€™ve gotten addicted to, had it went the wrong way, But I heard about how benzo withdrawal could kill you.) so I tried colonopin and realized they knocked me completely out cold during one day that I couldnâ€™t afford my daily habit. And I thought â€œthis is going to be my way out of this shit.â€ I stayed at my best friends for 5-7 days and dosed up just about enough colonopin to keep me asleep each day to not feel the withdrawal. And 7 days later I was finally able to take a full strip of suboxone without going into precip withdrawal. Whew was that a day to f*cking celebrate. But sadly did I know, going through that part was only half the battle. Now I had to stay that way. But I knew, in my head that I never EVER wanted to go back to living like that again, or should I say SURVIVING like that again. So I stayed clean for 11 months and I relapsed one day because of stress from my ex stealing my phone and car keys. That day I overdosed and was out for approximately 18 minutes before the first responders got there and narcan me. My poor brother found me like that, I woke up to him laying on top of my limp body begging me not to leave him here alone. Probably one of the most traumatic things me and him have ever gone through. That day was 15 months ago. Iâ€™ve been clean ever sinceâ€¦ I must say itâ€™s scary how peaceful it was to just be able to leave like that and not feel anything, because I know I used to think of harming myself but was too scared to do it. Now I know itâ€™s not a scary thing at all. But then I think of my brother and how heartbroken he was that day. I know he needs me. ğŸ¤¦ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸ğŸ˜¢  I still TO THIS DAY, think a lot about them YouTube videos I used to watch in the bathtub about the statistics about how most people die or never get clean. And I celebrate myself every single time I realize that I did it. I really f*cking did it. But now that im clean, I realize how hard it is to have to stay away from my mother since sheâ€™s on drugs, because sheâ€™s my MOM and I love her. But look at the situation her and her boyfriend got me in a couple years ago. Being an addict is hard but loving an addict is just as hard.

I made it to 27 before trying any illegal drugs. Tried mushrooms on my 27th, weed on my 29th, both just once. After losing my Doberman, then shortly after my grandad, I tried coke at 32 after his memorial while out with friends watching college football and said fuck it. I always turned it down but this time I was in a ditch of grief. Fast forward 2.5 years, I was using 1/2-1 ball a day for 18 months straight, sometimes with alcohol, while running my business, breaking my own standard of biz I had held so highly to build this business since I was 8. Luckily I didnâ€™t destroy what Iâ€™d built, but definitely lost a few clients. I ended up having a bender and psychotic episode and spent 12 day in hospital after trying to end my life. Iâ€™ll be 5 years clean October 2024. Stay strong and literally take one day at a time with simple steps to build a daily routine back to normalcy. Having a set schedule of daily activities is key to not straying and also feeling like a purposeful contributor to the world. DO NOT stay quiet if youâ€™re struggling, ask for help and share your struggles with others you trust. I kept in childhood traumas that ended up biting me after 30. God bless everyone

Big fan Joyner, but as a drug and alcohol rehab counselor, I can assure you the science is in consensus on the disease of addiction. Consider yourself lucky you don't have this disease or didn't have to get surgeries, and before you've healed up, you are chemically addicted, then the pills you were prescribed get too expensive, and now you are the type of sick nobody can bear. It can befall any type of person, and it is important that people know that so they don't assume, for whatever reason, it can't happen to them. "I'm too smart, have too good morals, etc... it doesn't work like that. You have a huge platform, educate yourself on the subject so you can spread the right messages. Keep Rocken, tho fam, you are gifted.

This one hurt, but in a good way, @JoynerLucasOfficial A way that is needed for people to understand that you are not them and can't force them to see a better way. They have to make the choice for a better life.   For years and years I've lost family and friends to addiction.  Despite the fact that they were given a better path and provided inspiration toward a better mindset, I was always the bad guy because I wanted better for them and hoped that they'd see a better path in life. Did this over and over until I wasted my breath and energy so I eventually gave up and did what's best for me, regardless of how regretful it felt.  It's like raising a child; you can guide them, but overall, you have to let them do what they want to do in life in order to find themselves regardless of your worries and fears.

My cousin that I grew up with is like my brother, and when he was in high school he got addicted to meth, we had an intervention and he went to rehab. Now we are both 31 and he's not on drugs anymore but he's an alcoholic and he's just not dealing with his shit. And now I can only love him from a distance and accept that he has his own journey. And that's OK. Unconditional love means loving people as they are and not only if they are the person you want them to be. But that doesn't mean bending over backwards and sacrificing your peace for someone just cuz you love them. It's ok to choose you, that's you loving yourself. It took me years before I fully felt comfortable accepting this and that's OK too. â¤

battling addiction is just a way to cope, well it was for me. I just hoped it would pass the time and numb me enough to forget. Maybe it did help but the time passing did. Depression and mental illness is a pendulum , it not a one day youre okay. It comes in waves and you just need to battle to cope. With addiction comes losing yourself, lying and running from those who care, its not because you dont know that, its because it gets confusing and then you ask if you really deserve it. For me keeping those closest close and being honest with yourself changes everything, once you discover the problem wasnt you but it now is, thats when things start to change. Its never too late to get help or get through the toughest of times, become the student of yourself and learn from it all. It does get better, I promise

Any body else thinks he looks like â€œJeyâ€ from raw on his picture??? Or is it me?
Did OC 80's for a few years after prescription Oxycodone got a hold of me from broken bones snowboarding for years. Almost watch my best friend die on his birthday from smoking heroine collapsing his lung, and then his hook would bring him OC to the hospital on visits. Snorted and smoked OC's and after watching everything unravel, I went cold turkey, the feeling of withdrawals was the worst experience of my life. I lost my job and had no money and would buy pills with the bonds my grandparents gave me as a child.  I moved away have been clean for 10 years plus. I now have my own place, 2 cars, invested money, and make 80k a year in 1.4k hours a year. It's possible to change your life. I did all this without ever scaring my family of my problem. This song hits home so much I'm telling my small story to strangers, a story I don't openly talk about.

Itâ€™s been a little over a year since I lost my father to a fentanyl overdose. I think about it every day. This song is so strong and resonates so hard with me. Growing up with an addict for a parent, and then becoming an addict myself, I have been on both sides of this fence. Now that I am sober and a father I want nothing more than to stay sober for my kids. Joyner and Jelly, I love you guys. Thanks for all you do for us and thanks for taking the time to write something that can touch us so much. Iâ€™ve been stuck listening to this song on repeat since it found me yesterday. I hope one day I can shake your hand, look you in your eyes, and tell you how much I appreciate what you do for us. Itâ€™s music like this that makes me want to get back to making music.

Pray I don't get a phone call that those very ones is dead. Now somehow I have to find myself again and try to rebuild my relationships back with my kids. Not because I was on drugs, but because I became addicted in trying to help someone who will never help themselves..

Facts ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯ğŸ’¯
Not sure where to even start as I'm typing this but I am 27 and my mother who has been struggling with alcohol addiction for the last 4-5 years just passed away on March 7th, 2024 at the age of 57... We still don't know exactly what happened but she passed away after trying and ultimately failing to walk home from a nearby hospital that she had been taken to after I found her in her room having fallen down drunk and hit her head... Hearing this song and in particular the lyrics of the chorus, "how can you love someone and learn to let them go", hits me extremely hard for so many reasons, not least of which being that I was not ready to lose her and now being forced to let her go is the hardest thing I have ever had to go through, but also because I had tried more times than I can count to get her to stop drinking and go to treatment or get help but to no real avail and had spent the last few weeks before she passed giving her space and not really talking in the hopes that since all else had failed she would reach out when she was ready only for her to end up getting worse and passing so unexpectedly and now that she is gone I cant help but wish I had done more or tried harder to get through to her or even just been there to try and make the most of the time we had left... It's been weeks and I have struggled everyday without her but I felt compelled to share in the hopes that maybe my story along with this song and the community here can help someone going through something similar, even if its just to let them know they aren't alone... Thank you to Joyner and Jelly Roll for your beautiful art and R.I.P. to my beautiful mother Lydia, I love you always and forever

Truly amazing song, but what I really want to comment on here is Jelly Roll. The first song of his that I ever heard was "pop another pill" with Lil Wyte. A catchy song, ngl, but since then I had written him off as just another crunk-era drug rapper talking about syrup, lean, etc. and never really took him seriously or looked into him beyond that. Hearing his voice in this chorus totally blew me away, like "WTF HE CAN SING?!" And just now I'm looking into his catalogue and discovering so much good music I never thought I'd like. I've never been much of a "country head", but from what I've heard, Jelly Roll's music is deep, soulful, and talking about real issues a lot of us go through, which I think is what "real" country music is supposed to be, rather than your typical "guns, beer, Jesus, yee-haw 'murica" stuff. Anyway, thank you Joyner and Jelly Roll for making great music that helps us get through tough times, keep up the good work, god bless ğŸ™

In the end, the resolution was passed.  Ms. Chen said, â€œThe rest of the world strictly controls organ transplants. Through this joint consensus I hope Taiwan will soon complete legislation on organ transplants, enabling people to know the source of the organs, and that there is legal monitoring. Nobody in their right mind would choose a drug over a loved one. The nucleus accumbens is literally reprogrammed to place priority on the drug over everything else. This reprogramming is not a choice. Itâ€™s a physical and permanent change unless something drastic is done to reprogram it. Shoutout to Everyone fighting addiction and Winning.I know its a daily struggle but yall doing it..Drugs are glorified now and its a shame because it ruins lives and families..This was needed and appreciated..
it annoys me so bad when i hear the "addiction is a choice not a disease" idiots saying stupid shit. addiction isnt called a disease so addicts can push teh blame on someone or something else. part of recovery is admitting youire an addict and admitting youre powerless over it. you dont get clean by making excuses. the ONLY people who think theres some excuse to use because its called a disease are the people who are NOT addicts and NOT understanding why its labeled that..  diseases are diseases when they meet the following criteria. diseases are Progressive (gets worse over time). chronic (long lasting and difficult to eradicate). and fatal (if left unchecked it will kill you)... diseases are progressive, chronic, and fatal... addiction is progressive, chronic, and fatal...   addiction being a disease isnt to be used as an excuse to keep using, its so doctors and psychologists and psychiatrists and scientists can better understand exactly what is happening scientifically so more ways to achieve recovery are invented. cousin johny shooting up dope in a bando on clinton ave while going to outpatient to get soboxone to sell it for dope every month, thats not who you should be listening to. if HE uses addiction being a disease as a reason to keep using then thats on him. but there are millions and millions and millions of recovered addicts all around the world who did get clean and stayed clean. like myself with coming up on 7 years clean from IV heroin, crack, fentynal, coke. ive slept under bridges in the winter. ive lived in bandos with no power in the winter. ive sold everything i own for drugs. Ive stolen from family to get high and get off sick. i WAS that piece fo shit garbage human being. i WAS cousin johny at the outpatient clinic pretending to be clean so i could sell my scrip every month. felony drug court saved my life and ive been clean ever since. not all addicts are those fuck ups who refuse to get it right. some of us wanted it enough to make it happen. we do recover. and the progression of the research around addiction is how people will get clean in the future. advancements in medication and programs and research and all the shit that happens above my pay grade to bring new methods of getting clean to market. like  naloxone implants which didnt exist even 10 years ago.   so yeah, people have used addiction being a disease as an excuse, for sure. but thats not the norm and nobody in recovery agrees with them. if youre an addict the ONLY correct move is to get clean by any means necessary. making excuses and continuing to use isnt how you get clean. addiction is a disease that started from a choice. same as any other disease that started from a choice. if i choose to fuck a hooker and catch aids that doesnt make the aids any less of a disease because i chose to fuck a hooker. people need to focus on the right things. and if you dont know what youre talking about then dont feel entitled to an opinion because there are real lives hanging in the mix.

Now watching one of my brother's struggle with alcohol. ğŸ˜¢  I struggled with substances going on 4 years ago.  I became homeless when I was SOBER, after my family forced my great grandma into a nurisng home.  I tried my best to maintain a job while having my 2 year old and 2 cats in my car on the streets where we slept. A friend took me to a club, and i started working there, 6 months later with no hope, I started to use a substance. 9 months goes by and I finally chose to stop, no one told me to stop, I didn't go to jail, simply just because I wanted to be the mom for my child that I didn't have and I wanted to love myself.    Drugs suck and our mental health needs to be taken care of the RIGHT way.  Sending love and hope to anyone struggling with any kind of addiction. You aren't alone

Just got clean a month ago and everyday I live terrified that I won't be strong enough to fight it just felt good to numb the feelings.was just so overwhelming all the time. I feel the pressure. Was forced to get on methadone from CPS but now I feel right back where I started sick if I miss more then one day at the clinic. Don't know if I got the strength to fight getting off that too. I quit cold turkey, no comfort meds nothing. I was completely off of everything. I did it. All to have my kids leveraged over me that if I didn't do what they felt I needed to do I wouldn't have my kids. Mind you since the beginning of this case I've passed every single drug test. I was clean before the case even came about. Now I feel like I'm still of drugs, something is still controlling me because I know I miss 2 days at the clinic and I'm drowning again in the cold sweats, the runny nose, the hot flashes, body aches and nausea. So really how did that help me. I just feel like I failed again.

You know that the last thing an addict needs is to lose anybody that could be a support system once they are clean. You can still love them and be there for them, without enabling them. When they lose everyone, they lose any want of recovery and the only thing thats left is their DOC. Addiction is like having the devil in one ear saying "this is all you have left, its the only thing that still loves you." Support systems are huge positives for an addict. You can encourage them but let the decision up to them. You can't force an addict to get clean, they have to want it for themselves. If its forced, it won't be long until they relapse, in majority of the situations.

My uncle pushed the whole family away. I loved him to death and wanted to see him do better. Always believed he could kick his addiction and return to the person that I knew. He was never the same after becoming addicted. He would kick the habit for a few days to a few weeks or months, then he kicked it for a year or two only to fall back into that state. While he was addicted, he stole from every last one of his family members, including me as a teenager. I forgave him time and time again, but there was a breaking point where I stopped caring about his well-being or existence because I simply had to do what was "best for me". I've had several friends die from addictions to hard drugs. I was always there for them but because of my experience with my  uncle, I learned that you cannot force change upon people who do not want to change. These mind altering drugs are a poison and I wish our society would realize this and push back against them.

I truly believe if you're there and push someone to be that better person when you do know they're struggling, most people will become that. A lot of it stems from having nobody or just feeling like they have nobody or who even gives a fuck? Just show someone you give a fuck and you may be surprised. Just be there for them, stay strong for them and let them know you're always going to be there. Everyone needs something to hold on to and someone to hold them down. Addiction is a horrible thing and most don't want to do it just to do it. It gets to a point they do it because it's what they feel they need to to get by but if you can get them away and take their heart to New heights, and get them past that few days of FOR REAL feeling like total shit, it's all mental after that. Abandoning them will never fix it and it will definitely never help. Just take them away before they lose themselves.

As a guy in recovery from a pretty bad heroin addiction. Thank you. Felt this one.
Today marks my 5th year in sobriety....this shit is a disease. It wasn't always easy but it's true. One can change their ways, takes hard work, takes being vulnerable, becoming accountable for all the damage and hurt we've caused...Life goes on, shit happens but knowing I have a choice is what gives me strength everyday to not throw it all away for a drink or using. It no longer consumes me...just for today. Because that is all I can do just for today. Sharing my experience, strength, and hope is  something I continue to do to those who are still suffering. I don't want to keep what I've gotten, I want to give it away because it is truly a wonderful and blessing of a gift. So for anyone who reads this and may be suffering, you're not alone. You don't have to be. You can change. Just don't give up.

I know people who got thirty years sober. I have 11 months. I even quit the weed. AA offers steps, principles, tenants, and prayers to connect you with God and repair relationships.  What I found is that we as addicts and alcoholics have to break out of that victim psyche. We truly have some of the best hearts and with fentanyl in everything nowadays. Using just isn't worth it at all anymore. And drugs and alcohol make every problem worse. You can change, I did, and I was using for 7 years on and off. What ensued were psyche wards, rehabs, and me not admitting I had a problem. My cousin, an addiction specialist kept telling me theres light at the end of the tunnel. I then started to realize, I had to stop. I went through sponsorship to Oak Forest Recovery in Southern California, where I got sober. Sometimes, all we need is a change of environment and people who want to see us win. Good luck to you, all my brothers and sisters. Ps. Joyner, thank you, bro!

ddiction. The word itself carries weightâ€”a black hole that swallows hope, leaving behind only echoes of what once was. It is the sirenâ€™s call, the seductive whisper promising relief. And yet, it is also the abyss that consumes, leaving shattered lives in its wake.  Honesty. Here lies the heart of it all. To peel back the layers, to reveal the raw nerve beneath. This portrayal does not flinch; it does not avert its gaze. It says, â€œLook. See. Understand.â€ And perhaps, in that stark illumination, there lies redemption.  So we stand here, at the crossroads, memories swirling like autumn leaves. The past whispers, the present beckons. And we chooseâ€”to fight, to heal, to reclaim what was lost. For in this honest portrayal, we find not condemnation but communion. This right here is what makes him a genius...he can give u hits for the club but most importantly write lyrics that have the ability to reach down into the pits of your soul & speak the words you just havnt had the ability to put together yourself to describe the lives of so many but especially your own. We all can take his lyrics & relate it to our lives regardless of age, skin color, community or background to which we belong.   Ima white 46yr old Momma & Gmomma...half of my family is black & what Joyner has done for me is enable me to speak to & connect with my black sons on a deeper level that i didnt even realize we were in need of. Thats the mark or a true artist. Hes way more than a rapper...To me & mine -hes a truth speaker...a therapist...a activist...a teacher...one of those rare artist that comes along & uses his talent to positively influence & impact the lives of those who listen to & appreciate his gift in the way its meant to be interpreted. & with the state of the culture...musically...were in rn his voice is whats desperately needed.  This is the type of artist that should be pushed & promoted to the masses on a higher level...i read the comments of those saying - "why is Joyner so underrated" ...& i get what yal mean by inquiring that but i also just wanna remind yal that WE determine the level of an artist based upon how their able to impact us...& as long as we as individuals continue to listen to & support him by playing his songs & posting comments letting him know what he means to us he could never be "underrated" because we the fans are what gives him the fuel to continue sharing & speaking to us on the level that he does. My point being....we know whos important ..whos the best lyrically, whos making the most impact & whos absolutely vital to the world based upon the way hes making us feel & how he drives us to take the time to make these comments were making rn ...idk about yal but i dont bother posting or speaking on those that are irrelevant & arent speaking directly to me... So it doesnt matter what or who radio or corporate music media moguls decide to push &  promote... no matter how many diff cooks are in the kitchen...WE ARE IN CONTROL & WE DECIDE what we wanna eat to feed our souls.  We gotta stop worrying about what others dont recognize or acknowledge as greatness...let folks stay in their ignorance...our job is to enjoy what were smart enough to realize as masterful artistic genius when we hear it. Peace & Blessings to all who took the time to read my rant...ğŸ˜‚

Joyner Saved HipHopğŸ™ğŸ½
I was raised an only child and always wanted a sibling. The closest I ever got to that was my cousin. Even though we were the same age, growing up I always looked up to him as the "big brother" I never had. As time went on however, we grew apart. Whereas I went onto get good grades and a job, he ended up joining a gang and getting arrested repeatedly. Just a few days ago, I received a call informing me that he did meth for the first time and went insane, attempting to murder his neighbors. I'm in tears as I type this because I know this time around when he goes to prison he's most likely not getting back out. I feel regret because I feel like there's something I should've said or did years ago to help him get his life back on track. Don't make the same mistake I did. If there's someone you care about, take action while you still have the chance.

Joyner my daughter loves your songs, so so much. She's going through depression, it's been 12 years now. This year she's turning 30 and she's been saying for years now that she won't make it to that birthday .. she's tried to take her life twice and thank god she failed. I don't want there to be a third. She was also diagnosed with anxiety & recently with adhd. We've tried everything to help her, we haven't stopped, but I don't know what else to do. If I may ask, could you please make a song like this, where people hear both sides of the story but about her situation? I know many more are going through the same & it would also be helping all of those people too.. Music has a lot of power, that's a fact, and she already has days where she won't even listen to music no more. If you do read this, please consider it. Thank you
